title: Leadership is not easy in an age of uncertainty
text:
There were four different policies for dealing with climate change during that 10-year period that were either abandoned because of internal party splits, failed to pass parliamentary muster, or were casualties of changes in government. At the same time there were six prime ministerships and nine changes of leader in the Liberal and Labor Parties – slightly less than one a year. Small wonder the BBC crowned Australia “the coup capital of the democratic world.”

Reflecting how aberrant this period has been, in the post-war period there have been three prime ministers who won four or more elections in a row – Liberal John Howard, Labor’s Bob Hawke, and Liberal Party founder Sir Robert Menzies, who won seven in a row. Howard served in office for 11½ years, Hawke for 8½ years and Menzies for a record 17 years.

Let’s hope our current crop of politicians improve their performance, and then some, in the coming decade. They will need to because there are dark clouds wherever you look – from the US-China trade war to Brexit to the bizarre Donald Trump presidency. The latter has “an almost preternatural ability to make any foreign policy worse”, commented the Financial Times’ Charles Gardner following Trump-triggered mayhem in northern Syria, although the US secured a ceasefire in the region by the end of the week.

Threat of impeachment

Then there is the mother of all political campaigns preceding the November 2020 US presidential election. A near Melbourne Cup field of Democratic candidates is vying for the nomination to take on President Trump, who is himself facing a threat of impeachment. It’s a drawn-out process that is avowedly legal but is in fact intensely political.

It starts off in the Democratic Party-controlled US House of Representatives. Assuming Trump is in fact impeached by the lower house for what the US Constitution calls “high crimes and misdemeanours”, it will end in a post-impeachment trial in the Republican Party-controlled Senate. There a two-thirds majority vote is required to confirm any lower house impeachment decision.

Meanwhile, a climate of political crisis is de rigueur in Trump’s America. This has in turn influenced a global mood of trepidation undermining what British economist John Maynard Keynes referred to as ”animal spirits”, or the sort of energetic optimism that powers economic expansion.

Exacerbating this negative vibe is the spectre of global economic stagnation. This has a number of possible causes, including the longer-term ageing process and lack of population growth in China and Europe. “Demography is destiny,” as former treasurer (and now chairman of Nine Entertainment, which publishes this newspaper) Peter Costello once pointed out.

Advertisement

Of course, there are other influences. According to the latest IMF global economic outlook, the US-China trade war will reduce world economic growth to 3 per cent this year – the lowest rate since the GFC hit in 2008. This could worsen if trade tensions between the superpowers continue, the IMF says, and it has scaled back Australia’s growth rate for this year to a paltry 1.7 per cent.

Backing the latest IMF global economic prognosis, research jointly sponsored by the Democratic Party-leaning, Washington-based, Brookings Institution and the Financial Times says the world has entered a period of “synchronised stagnation”. Paradoxically, this comes two years after forecasts that the world was embarking on a period of “synchronised growth” after Trump-mandated tax cuts in the US.

Those Trump tax cuts may have turned out to be more of a sugar hit, although current unemployment rates in countries like the US (3.7 per cent) and even Australia (5.2 per cent) remain healthy. But Costello’s “demography-destiny" paradigm has an important role.

Mediocre figures

In two reports published this year and in 2018, the IMF warned that future “demographic developments will continue to apply downward pressure on the interest rates in Asia which foresees a rapid ageing”. Further, a low birth rate and population decline in large parts of Europe “will have significant implications for growth, living standards and fiscal sustainability”, according to the IMF.

Confirming its reputation as the dismal science, there are differing views among economists about whether the current mix of mediocre figures and forecasts will translate into a global recession, or otherwise. But policy makers are struggling to find a way to jump-start growth amid the constraints of high debt levels and record low interest rates, not to mention lower confidence.

For example, local economic policy settings continue to be cautious. The Scott Morrison-led Coalition government argues it must fulfil its promise to return the budget to surplus in the 2019-20 financial year as insurance against a declining global scene.

"Surpluses are not ends in themselves,” Treasurer Josh Frydenberg told the Financial Review’s Phillip Coorey before he jetted off to Washington to attend an IMF meeting. “They're not trophies on a cabinet table. They're actually an indication of strong budget management, and helping to build the resilience in the Australian economy so you can weather those economic shocks.''

It’s more than a fair bet that the Coalition’s assumptions behind its fiscal restraint will be sorely tested in coming years.
description: After almost ten years of self-inflicted angst over climate policy, real economic pressures are starting to pile up again.
